conclusion: We have: - A plank of length L = 0.60 m and mass M = 0.40 kg leaning against a smooth vertical wall - A block (point mass) of mass m = 0.80 kg at the lower right of the plank - Force F1 applied horizontally to the left on the block - Force F2 applied vertically upward on the plank - Coefficient of friction (both static and kinetic) between block and plank: μ = 0.20 - Gravity: g = 10 m/s² The goal is to find the condition on F1 that makes the plank move upward.

A plank is leaning against a smooth vertical wall with a block at the lower right of the plank. Force F1 is applied horizontally to the left on the block, and force F2 is applied vertically upward on the plank.

premise: Weight of the plank: M × g = 0.40 × 10 = 4 N downward
conclusion: The weight of the plank is 4 N downward.

premise: Weight of the block: m × g = 0.80 × 10 = 8 N downward
conclusion: The weight of the block is 8 N downward.

Since the plank is leaning against the wall, let's use a coordinate system aligned with the plank: - x-axis along the plank (positive upward along the plank) - y-axis perpendicular to the plank (positive toward the plank)

premise: Normal force on block: N_block = m g cosθ + F1 sinθ
conclusion: The normal force on the block is N_block = m g cosθ + F1 sinθ.

premise: Friction force: f = μ N_block = μ(m g cosθ + F1 sinθ)
conclusion: The friction force is f = μ(m g cosθ + F1 sinθ).
From the problem description, the plank is leaning against a vertical wall. The length of the plank is L = 0.60 m.

premise: For the block to move upward along the plank, the sum of forces along the plank must be positive: F1 cosθ - m g sinθ - f > 0
conclusion: The condition for upward motion is F1 cosθ - m g sinθ - f > 0.

premise: Substituting the friction force: F1 cosθ - m g sinθ - μ(m g cosθ + F1 sinθ) > 0
conclusion: The condition becomes F1 cosθ - m g sinθ - μ(m g cosθ + F1 sinθ) > 0.

premise: Rearranging: F1 (cosθ - μ sinθ) > m g (sinθ + μ cosθ)
conclusion: The rearranged condition is F1 (cosθ - μ sinθ) > m g (sinθ + μ cosθ).

premise: Therefore: F1 > m g (sinθ + μ cosθ) / (cosθ - μ sinθ)
conclusion: The condition for F1 is F1 > m g (sinθ + μ cosθ) / (cosθ - μ sinθ).
